title: 114_hr470
content: The "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015" allows for the disposal of isolated National Forest System land in Georgia to be sold for public interest. Proceeds will be used by the Forest Service to purchase land for National Forest purposes in the state. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange United States' rights in National Forest System land in Georgia. The land authorized for disposal consists of 30 tracts totaling 3,841 acres, depicted on maps dated September 24, 2013. The Secretary may modify boundaries of the land for management purposes. Land sold under this Act will be conveyed by quitclaim deed with reservations for rights-of-way. The Secretary cannot sell land for less than market value. (d) Valuation requires land to be sold at market value determined by appraisal or competitive bid. Appraisals must follow specific standards and be approved by the Secretary. Consideration for sales must be paid in cash, and the Secretary can accept cash payments exceeding 25% of the land value in exchanges. The Secretary may sell land through public or private sale, including competitive auctions, and may solicit offers for land sales or exchanges. Brokers or third parties can be used in the land disposition process. The Secretary may use brokers or third parties to sell land authorized by this Act and pay commissions or fees from the sale proceeds. SEC. 4. TREATMENT OF PROCEEDS. The Secretary shall deposit sale proceeds in the fund established under Public Law 90-171. Amounts deposited shall be available for land acquisition in Georgia without further appropriation. Funds cannot be used to acquire land without owner consent.
